title: Mina (unit)
text:
The mina (also mĕnē, <a href="Aramaic%20language">Aramaic</a>; ) is an ancient <a href="Near%20East">Near East</a>ern unit of weight, which was divided into 60 <a href="shekels">shekels</a>. The mina, like the shekel, was also a unit of <a href="currency">currency</a>.
History.
The word mina comes from the ancient <a href="Semitic%20root">Semitic root</a> / 'to count', <a href="Akkadian%20language">Akkadian</a> , (), / (/), (), . It is mentioned in the Bible, where Solomon is reported to have made 300 shields, each with 3 "mina" of gold (), or later after the Edict of <a href="Cyrus%20II%20of%20Persia">Cyrus II of Persia</a> the people are reported to have donated 5000 mina of silver for the reconstruction of <a href="Solomon%27s%20Temple">Solomon's Temple</a> in <a href="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>.
From earliest <a href="History%20of%20Sumer">Sumerian</a> times, a mina was a unit of weight. At first, talents and shekels had not yet been introduced. By the time of <a href="Ur-Nammu">Ur-Nammu</a> (shortly before 2000 BCE), the mina had a value of <a href="Talent%20%28weight%29">talents</a> as well as 60 <a href="shekel">shekel</a>s. The weight of this mina is calculated at .
Writings from <a href="Ugarit">Ugarit</a> give the value of a mina as equivalent to fifty shekels. The prophet <a href="Ezekiel">Ezekiel</a> refers to a mina ("maneh" in the <a href="King%20James%20Version">King James Version</a>) also as 60 shekels, in the <a href="Book%20of%20Ezekiel">Book of Ezekiel</a> 45:12. <a href="Jesus%20of%20Nazareth">Jesus of Nazareth</a> tells the "<a href="parable%20of%20the%20minas">parable of the minas</a>" in <a href="Gospel%20of%20Luke">Luke</a> 19:11–27, also told with the <a href="Talent%20%28measurement%29">talent</a> unit of weight in <a href="Gospel%20of%20Matthew">Matthew</a>. In Jewish usage, the is equal in weight to 100 .
From the <a href="Akkadian%20Empire">Akkad</a>ian period, 2 mina was equal to 1 of water (cf. <a href="water%20clock">clepsydra</a>, water clock).
In <a href="ancient%20Greece">ancient Greece</a>, it originally equalled 70 <a href="drachmae">drachmae</a> and later was increased to 100 drachmae. The Greek word () was borrowed from Semitic; compare Hebrew , Aramaic , Syriac , Ugaritic , and Akkadian .
